#Text=3. Methodology
#Text=3.1 .
#Text=Structure of Hymod Model
#Text=A parsimonious conceptual rainfall-runoff model structure of the Hymod model was adopted in this case study .
#Text=The Hymod model has been widely applied in hydrological modeling and provided satisfactory performance .
#Text=This five-parameter model is based on the probability-distribution model ( PDM ) proposed by Moore and was originally introduced by Boyle et al. .
#Text=As shown in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=a , the model structure consists of two main components , which are the rainfall excess component and the routing component .
#Text=Table 2 presents a brief description of the free parameters of the Hymod model .
#Text=The core of the Hymod model is a two-parameter nonlinear tank with a rainfall excess component .
#Text=In order to split the rainfall into direct runoff and subsurface runoff , this tank statistically describes the heterogeneous spatial distribution of soil moisture storage capability .
#Text=It is hypothesized that the soil moisture storage capacity varies across the catchment and has a maximum soil moisture storage capacity , .
#Text=Thus , this tank allows deriving the saturated proportion of a catchment and its relative saturation .
#Text=In practice , a Pareto distribution function describes the fraction of the catchment having a storage capacity .

#Text=( 1 ) where denotes the soil moisture storage capacity , is the maximum soil moisture storage capacity in the catchment , and parameter defines the degree of spatial variability of storage capacities over the catchment ( see
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=a ) .
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=b demonstrates the examples of Equation ( 1 ) , which is plotted for different values of attention .
#Text=The corresponding probability density function of the soil moisture storage capacity is shown below .
#Text=( 2 )
#Text=A similar function is also employed in the Xinanjiang model and the Variable Infiltration Capacity ( VIC ) model .
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=a illustrates that the area producing fast runoff is calculated from the proportion of the catchment with saturated reservoirs .
#Text=The effective rainfall is equal to the soil moisture excess calculated at each time step .
#Text=The routing component consists of two series of linear reservoirs , a single reservoir for the slow flow , and three identical quick flow reservoirs (
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=a ) .
#Text=The slow flow reservoir , modelled using one linear reservoir , represents the groundwater .
#Text=The quick flow is routed by surface runoff using a cascade of three linear quick flow reservoirs .
#Text=A more detailed description of the Hymod model can be found in Moore .
#Text=3.2 .
#Text=Semi-Distributed Model Setup
#Text=In this study , the Hymod model was set up using a semi-distributed modelling system .
#Text=The semi-distributed scheme was applied in two catchments , which had been respectively delineated into three sub-catchments .
#Text=Modelling at each sub-catchment was performed using the lumped version of the Hymod model .
#Text=The river routing between sub-catchments was conducted by a linear Muskingum river model .
#Text=The forcing data ( i. e. , precipitation and potential evapotranspiration ) was interpolated , according to sub-catchment boundaries with the purpose of running a semi-distributed model .
#Text=Only the streamflow data at the outlet station were used for calibration .
#Text=The lumped Hymod model was run at each sub-catchment , and the same set of parameters was estimated for all sub-catchments .
#Text=Since the amount of sub-catchment is small and the area of each sub-catchment is similar , two parameters in the Muskingum routing model were both treated as homogeneous .
#Text=As a result , in addition to the parameters of the Hymod model , the Muskingum river model has two free parameters that need to be calibrated .
#Text=3.3 .
#Text=Prior Estimation of the Degree of Parameter β
#Text=The prior estimation of the was conducted by using SMAP root-zone soil moisture data based on the method of moments .
#Text=As mentioned in Section 3.1 , is the shape parameter of Pareto distribution , which was utilized to describe the spatial variability of soil moisture storage capability .
#Text=This spatial distribution can be related to different soil moisture storage capacity among the study catchment .
#Text=The form of the curve of the spatial distribution of soil moisture storage capacity is shown in Equation ( 2 ) , and the first theoretical moment of Equation ( 2 ) is shown below .

#Text=For each cell of SMAP data , the soil moisture storage capacity sample of the i -th cell could be estimated as follows : ( 5 ) ( 6 ) ( 7 ) where means the SMAP root-zone soil moisture for the i -th cell at the time step , is the total number of time steps , and is the depth of the root zone .
#Text=Note that Equation ( 7 ) is based on the assumption that the soil moisture will reach the maximum and minimum soil wetness at least once during the study period .
